content:
Yes, you can combine the two scripts into one. Here's an example:
```
import pandas as pd

#Read in the csv file
df = pd.read_csv('your_file.csv')

#Filter the dataframe to rows where the values in column "CPT" and "BlueHost" are equal to the specified values
df_filtered = df[(df['CPT'] == 'your_cpt_value') & (df['BlueHost'] == 'your_BlueHost_value')]

#Create a new dataframe containing each unique combination of the "CPT" column and the "BlueHost" column
df_grouped = df_filtered.groupby(['CPT','BlueHost']).size().reset_index(name='counts')

#Output the grouped dataframe to a new excel file with a specified tab name
df_grouped.to_excel('filtered_data.xlsx', sheet_name='your_tab_name', index=False)
```
You will have to replace "your\_file.csv" with the name of your csv file, "your\_cpt\_value" and "your\_BlueHost\_value" with the values you want to filter the dataframe on, and 'your\_tab\_name' with the tab name you want the sheet to have in the excel file. Note that now the new dataframe `df_grouped` will have three columns, "CPT","BlueHost" and "counts" where "counts" column tells you the number of rows for each unique combination of the "CPT" and "BlueHost" columns from the filtered dataframe.
